review_title: Nurse Bullying Culture-Dehumanizing treatment by fellow staff.
job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Loma Linda, CA
pros: Beautiful facility, plenty of equipment and supplies. Level 1 trauma center and teaching facility. 2 stars for this!
cons: Worst bully- nurse culture I have ever seen (I did not know nurse bullying was truly an issue until coming here); where even the charge nurses partake in snide comments, exclusion, not offering breaks, and outwardly putting down other staff in front of them. As an experienced ICU (6 years) nurse I was surprised by the haughty and blatantly rude nature of even the new grad nurses (whom have clearly learned from their seniors). I put in my notice and left after 3 months. I have never before or after, seen a facility tolerate RNs that yell at others (to the extent where others including charge RN came to intervene) where it was ok to throw and slam things. All because one doesn't like there assignment? It is interesting, starting a shift with peace and prayer, then staff acting in such a monstrous way to fellow nurses. The beautiful facility is not worth feeling like a shell- of- a-human after a shift.

pros: I enjoy my patients, and it is close to home for me.
cons:
Cons: I don’t really enjoy the work environment. Very clicky. If you speak up you will be retaliated against. Lots of favoritism among senior staff.

Not a lot of room for improvement or transferring. In fact, it feels as if management disapproves of it and will do everything in their power to avoid advancement. I do not feel supported by leadership at this organization, so much, that my director has probably only rounded a handful of times in my department. Leadership is very disconnected with staff. A lot of the senior staff have been at this facility since the hospital opened and they are NOT open for change. Very set in their ways, in a bad way... 

Benefits are not that great. The employee insurance requires you to use providers within the LLU network, and can be difficult to get appointments/referrals. Sick pay is a joke! You get one PTO bank. So if you get sick, you quickly deplete your PTO. It’s terrible.

For a religious organization, I would expect the employees being treated better, recognized more often, and their needs to be taken into consideration – not the case…

pros: Great place to learn from in regards to dx, MD orders, improving upon skill sets.
cons:
Pay is well below living wages. They talk about “amazing benefits” which is a complete lie. Health insurance is tied only within llumc. So if you’re trying to get kaiser or other areas for health related aspects hopefully you’re married and your spouse has insurance elsewhere. My old unit had a toxic environment which lead to to leave the entity as a whole in regards to environment and pay status. There are other facilities where you can learn from and be taken care of. In regards to retirement ... it’s a joke. You can’t retire off the benefits they provide unless you feel like pouring your paycheck into your retirement ....but hey bc “bills don’t exist for anyone”. The hospital like to play into this whole “we don’t have money. Blah blah blah. Budget this budget that”. Do yourself a favor and don’t go here unless you’re planning to leave within 1 year to a better facility. 

Security is also a joke! There are real and present dangers to the workers from the population we serve such as being hit punched abused in every sense of the word. All security says is were working on the new hospital so security can be better. Like no we are here now! Do something! Lazy!  Also most of the time we called security it was a huge delay or they just flat out never came!

job_title: Unit Secretary in Loma Linda, CA
pros: It's a rewarding experience to be able to help others in need. Sometimes patients just needed that extra bit of attention to feel at ease, and I was always glad to do so. The job itself was easy after I got the hang of it as long as I kept my mouth shut and stayed close enough to be liked and at the same time kept my distance from the troublemakers to avoid the drama.
cons: You won't climb the ladder unless you are in the in - period. Office politics and drama run rampant at Loma Linda, religious beliefs sometimes get taken a little too far, and  the cliques are just awful. There was a lot of back stabbing, I actually witnessed trusted staff setting other employees up to purposely get them in trouble or make them look bad. I was told to do things one way by management that other department managers had specifically asked us not to do - putting me in the middle of conflicts that I wanted no part of. I stuck it out as long as I could while looking for another job and just finally left.

job_title: OR-RN in Loma Linda, CA
pros: People that have worked here are very experienced and willing to help new staff learn. If you want to learn and be one of the most competent health care workers in the field, then this is the place for you. cons: LLUMC has staff very experienced in what they do. Being part of a Level 1 trauma center in the IE can be a challenge that staff tends to burnout, as seen in a big turnover of staff in the operating room. Unfortunately LLUMC does not value their employees for their hard work they put in through out the years to the company. Knowledge or experience is not compensated well in LLUMC, as seen in many experienced employees that have been working for the company for many years and still getting 1/3 pay less than surrounding hospitals. Promotions for staff is seen by staff as a burden because of the expectations by leadership personal without much finical compensation. Due to the high turnover of staff, leadership also has taken its toll and many individuals that have the experience of many years in their background do not take this positions because they have toped-out their income and see no other benefit or compensation by taking leadership positions. Benefits are not as good as surrounding hospitals.

review_title: Abysmally poor management, no room for growth, toxic/hostile work environment.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Loma Linda, CA
pros: Full benefits package. Very stable long-term position. I had some co-workers who were my very good hangout buddies, and some of them are still my friends until now.  (But that's about it and nothing else.)
cons:
First of all, I was pretty much shocked when I saw some of the high ratings for this so-called spiritual and health-promoting place. It definitely didn't live up to its self-proclaimed hype. (At the time, I was still affiliated with the church that runs the organization.) Office politics galore. There was immature, unprofessional high school-type cliquish behavior all around, constant bullying and nit-picking, plus a mix of slacker, doormat, and tyrannical, micromanaging superiors in this one hot mess. This all happened on a very regular basis.

People who were in the clique were given special privileges while others got written up. Even two of my good friends in the department were wrongfully terminated. (Fortunately, one of them found a much better job elsewhere a few weeks later.) 

I brought the situation several times to the HR folks' attention. They were apparently in denial and they branded me as a troublemaker, and one of them even told me "not to rock the boat." At one point they sent me a referral to EAP. Instead of having my work-related concerns and issues addressed when I met the counselor, she asked me instead about my upbringing and my past romantic relationship. (What in Sam Hill?!)
 
The periodic Gallup polls as an opportunity for employees to rate the organization were a massive waste of time and company resources since apparently the powers that be didn't do anything to improve the situation. The management didn't really care at best and was mostly patronizing at worst. 

After a while in the department, there was nothing challenging or stimulating. It was stagnant. I was also denied opportunities to transfer to other departments, keeping me trapped there longer. Many employees there felt stuck and miserable (for the same reasons I left the organization), believing they wouldn't get any better job offer out there. They didn't want to lose the secure money and benefits and that kept them chained there. It was scary that the dynamics there in the department were a lot like those in a domestic violence situation. 

I had no choice but to cut my losses and submitted my resignation notice after having worked there for a few years. I decided to stop cosigning their nonsense, and they promptly released me that same day with a few "goodies" as a parting gift. I absolutely had ZERO regrets doing that and I never looked back. I even managed to not yield to the temptation of working for this organization again even when I needed money the most during the economic meltdown.

I'm actually not the one with the same complaints. I personally know MANY people with similar (or worse) experiences working at LLUMC. 

In short, LLUMC absolutely has no redeeming value whatsoever except for the generous benefits package it offers. (Well, at least I did put the insurance to very good use for my frequent stress-related symptoms!) 

If you're the free-spirited, creative NF/NFP type (BTW, I'm using Myers-Briggs terms for those of you who are familiar with the stuff), exit stage left before you even enter this institution. It's a horrible cultural fit for you as it's mostly populated by the conventional, rigid ST/STJ types.

Regardless of personality type, I still wouldn't really recommend this place for employment. There are TONS of better, more savvy organizations and companies out there. They know better. They recognize that bennies extend beyond the usual package of health/dental/vision/life insurance, retirement funds, etc. Many people want a positive, flexible, supportive, and accommodating lifestyle-affirming environment. 

Therefore, I'm awarding LLUMC only a one-star rating. It's actually 1 1/2 stars (the bonus 1/2 is for the benefits package), but there are no halves here. 

To be fair, there have been (are?) good departments with positive work environment, but there hasn't been any consistency with LLUAHSC quality across the board. So it's pretty much a crapshoot, really. You may or may not end up in a lousy department. 

This has left a really bad taste in my mouth, so until now I'm still affirming that the forgiving love of Jesus Christ is healing and releasing both me and the organization from the experience of the past and we all go free to be happy.
